tldr: Honeywell delivered Q4 2025 adjusted sales of $10.1B (+11% organic) and adjusted EPS of $2.59 as orders rose 23% and backlog topped $37B, led by Aerospace and Building Automation. Management guided 2026 sales of $38.8B-$39.8B (3%-6% organic) and adjusted EPS of $10.35-$10.65 while continuing portfolio actions (Solstice spin completed; PSS/WWS held for sale; automation/aerospace separation expected Q3 2026).
bullets: Q4 beat the high end of guidance on adjusted sales and adjusted EPS: adjusted sales $10.1B (+11% organic) and adjusted EPS $2.59, with organic orders +23% and backlog >$37B; free cash flow was $2.5B (+48%). GAAP EPS was $0.49 due to held-for-sale impairment and Flexjet-related litigation impacts.

Segments: Aerospace +21% organic (+13% commercial aftermarket, +10% defense/space) with adjusted margin 26.5% (benefiting from the prior-year Bombardier agreement comp); Building Automation +8% organic with margin 27.0%; Industrial Automation +1% organic driven by WWS (+5%), sensing (+3%), and PSS back to growth (+1%, double-digit orders) but margin fell to 18.4%; ESS -7% organic on petrochemical catalysts with margin 23.7%.

2026 outlook: sales $38.8B-$39.8B (+3% to +6% organic), segment margin 22.7%-23.1% (+20-60 bps), adjusted EPS $10.35-$10.65 and free cash flow $5.3B-$5.6B; PSS/WWS held for sale (sale process planned for 1H 2026) and automation/aerospace separation targeted for Q3 2026.
themes: Asset visibility and data capture adoption expanding
Pricing and cost pressure shaping margins
Industrial and logistics demand uneven by region

segments.title: Aerospace Technologies
points: Organic sales grew 21% (11% excluding the prior-year Bombardier agreement), led by commercial aftermarket (+13%) and defense and space (+10%); commercial OE growth accelerated with improving supply chain.
Adjusted segment margin expanded to 26.5% (up 620 bps) largely due to the Bombardier agreement comparability; excluding that effect, adjusted margin declined ~60 bps on cost inflation.

segments.title: Industrial Automation
points: Organic sales grew 1% as WWS rose 5% on pipeline conversion, sensing grew 3%, and PSS returned to growth (+1%) with double-digit orders; Process Solutions was flat as aftermarket services offset measurement and controls softness.
Segment margin declined 120 bps to 18.4% due to cost inflation, partially offset by commercial excellence and benefits from the PPE sale; core Process Solutions will move to PA&T reporting in 2026.

segments.title: Building Automation
points: Organic sales grew 8% (solutions +9% led by services; products +8%) with strength in North America and the Middle East; orders increased year over year and sequentially.
Segment margin improved 20 bps to 27.0% on commercial excellence and volume leverage, partially offset by inflation.

segments.title: Energy and Sustainability Solutions
points: Organic sales declined 7% on petrochemical catalysts reload softness; UOP orders grew on strong LNG demand and double-digit growth in refining and petrochemicals projects.
Segment margin declined 300 bps to 23.7% on mix and cost inflation; ESS will be reported within PA&T starting in 2026.

numbers.label: Adjusted segment margin
numbers.note: Q4 2025 (+240 bps YoY; -70 bps ex BBD)

notes.title: Portfolio actions and reporting changes
points: Solstice Advanced Materials was spun off on October 30, 2025 (ticker: SOLS) and Advanced Materials is reported as discontinued operations.

Following its strategic alternatives review, Honeywell classified PSS and WWS as held for sale (sale process planned for 1H 2026) to focus on core automation areas with long-term secular growth drivers.

Starting in 2026, Honeywell will report Aerospace Technologies, Building Automation, Industrial Automation, and Process Automation and Technology (PA&T); PA&T will include UOP and core Process Solutions, and the businesses in ESS will be reported within PA&T.

notes.title: One-time items and Flexjet settlement
points: Q4 operating income and GAAP EPS were pressured by a one-time impairment charge tied to the held-for-sale classification (PSS/WWS) and Flexjet-related litigation matter impacts.

Honeywell and Flexjet reached a comprehensive agreement announced January 21, 2026, including an extension of aircraft engine maintenance through 2035; the company disclosed a one-time cash payment in Q1 2026 that is excluded from full-year free cash flow guidance.

notes.title: 2026 outlook perimeter
points: 2026 guidance includes full-year expected results for Aerospace, PSS, and WWS and does not include the pending acquisition of Johnson Matthey's Catalyst Technologies business.

themes.title: Held-for-sale businesses and EMOB/warehouse exposure
points: Investors focused on how the intended sale of PSS and WWS reshapes Honeywell's automation portfolio and near-term operating cadence while those businesses are held for sale.

themes.title: 2026 guidance assumptions and new reporting structure
points: Management emphasized that 2026 guidance includes PSS and WWS for the full year and excludes the Catalyst Technologies acquisition, alongside a new PA&T segment that combines UOP and core Process Solutions.

themes.title: Aerospace growth and margin mix (BBD effect)
points: Discussion centered on aerospace demand durability and the margin bridge between reported results and performance excluding the Bombardier agreement comparability.

themes.title: Sale process timing and stranded-cost execution
points: Questions also centered on the timing for the PSS/WWS sales process and the pace of stranded-cost takeout as Honeywell prepares for the automation/aerospace separation.

top_questions.question: How does 2026 guidance treat PSS/WWS and the Catalyst Technologies acquisition?
top_questions.summary: Guidance includes full-year expected results for Aerospace, PSS, and WWS and excludes the Johnson Matthey Catalyst Technologies acquisition.

top_questions.question: What is the expected timing for the PSS and WWS sale process?
top_questions.summary: Honeywell indicated it intends to pursue a sale of PSS and WWS in the first half of 2026, with timing dependent on customary closing conditions and approvals.

top_questions.question: What milestones should investors track for the automation/aerospace separation?
top_questions.summary: Honeywell reiterated expectations to separate automation and aerospace in Q3 2026 and announced elements of an aerospace leadership team ahead of the planned separation.

top_questions.question: What drove the large gap between GAAP and adjusted results in Q4?
top_questions.summary: GAAP results reflected one-time impacts tied to the PSS/WWS held-for-sale classification and Flexjet-related litigation matters, which are excluded from adjusted results.

implications: The planned sale of PSS (AIDC/scanning + rugged mobility exposure) and WWS (warehouse workflow + voice) is a potential structural reset for the EMOB landscape: a separated asset could become a cleaner #2 EMOB comparable, but near-term customer/channel uncertainty could delay deployments and large refresh decisions.

PSS returned to organic growth in Q4 (+1%) with double-digit order growth, and WWS grew 5% organically, signaling improving demand in core data capture and warehouse workflows even as Industrial Automation margins remain pressured by inflation.

Honeywell's portfolio moves reinforce a broader industrial trend toward specialization; EMOB forecasts should treat Honeywell's current exposure as transitional until the divestiture perimeter and timing are clarified.
competitive_notes: Track how Honeywell and channel partners message roadmap continuity, support, and pricing for PSS/WWS during the held-for-sale period, as that will influence win/loss dynamics versus pure-play AIDC and warehouse automation vendors.
forecast_hooks: Watch for updates on timing and structure of PSS/WWS divestitures (single buyer vs separate processes) and any interim operational dis-synergies that could affect demand and margins.
Monitor PSS order trends and WWS pipeline conversion as leading indicators for EMOB and warehouse workflow spending through 2026.
Track Aerospace margin progression excluding the Bombardier agreement effect as pricing catches up to cost inflation.

action_items: Channel checks with AIDC resellers/integrators on customer demand, deal cycles, and any deferrals tied to PSS/WWS sale uncertainty.
Track any updates on the 1H 2026 PSS/WWS sale process (structure, buyer type, and carve-out readiness) and update EMOB competitive scenarios accordingly.
Refresh EMOB comparable-company framing once divestiture perimeter and standalone financial disclosures become clearer.
open_questions: What transitional services, licensing, and roadmap commitments will persist post-sale for PSS and WWS customers and partners?
Will Honeywell sustain product support and R&D cadence during the held-for-sale period to protect the installed base and partner ecosystem?
How quickly will catalyst reload demand improve versus UOP order momentum as PA&T becomes a reported segment in 2026?
watch_next_quarter: Any progress updates on the PSS/WWS sale process and any changes to the 2026 outlook perimeter (including Catalyst Technologies).
Aerospace backlog conversion and OE supply-chain execution versus aftermarket growth expectations.
Any disclosure updates that improve visibility into standalone PSS/WWS financials as potential EMOB comps.
